posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com: Why is it that carburator throttles are mounted vertically on an engine and that throttles for injection systems are mounted horizontally?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can I install tint (taillight/reflector) in 50-60 degree weather if I heat it up a bit with a heat gun? Should I head the piece I'm applying the tint to prior or just after, and how much heat is enough?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281198
Both fuel and air flow into the carburetor but fuel, being liquid, works better using gravity to reach the valvetrain and combustion chamber, so the throttle in the carburetor has to be placed horizontally.
Fuel and air intakes are separate in fuel injected engines, so the throttle bodies are able to be installed vertically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My can has both external cartridge filter and internal pan filter for my transmission fluid. Should I replace both at 100k? Also, my car has low transmission fluid but doesn't seem to be leaking anywhere what is going on? It's a mitsubishi mirage '14.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281712
It doesn't matter, anything in the bottom of the pan that can get lifted will get lifted when you drive, and sent to the filter. Oil changes are frequent enough that leaving some old oil in the pan is irrelevant.
As for the drain valve, you should consider the location of your plug in relation to other hard parts of your vehicle... is it going to get ripped off if you accidentally hit an unmarked speed bump at a higher than normal speed? My car sits low enough and the oil pan is relatively proud so I would be concerned about installing one on mine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281863
How long has it been since you serviced the transmission? It's a closed system but that doesn't mean that tiny amounts of fluid can't escape or burn up or whatever which over the years total up to a low fluid state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Took my car out for a drive and went over the speedometer limit for the first time and started smelling burning, is that normal? Not gonna lie it kind of spooked me and I let off the throttle and drove normal the rest of the way. Nothing seemed damaged under the hood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26285116
>>26285315
it's a flex plate actually, because it's just a piece of sheet metal that the converter bolts to and holds the ring gear vs a flywheel that is a weighted chunk of steel or aluminum. and no, it won't hurt it to run without the transmission and it won't start at all without the flex plate since, again, it has the ring gear. it might idle a little fast or unstable without all of the weight of the torque converter to stabilize it but it won't harm it.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26278689
>>26278696
There’s a few different types of extractors you can use. The threaded ones are like emergency use and you can grab the 2pk of them at auto parts stores for <$20, but after you thread an overtightened lug into there backwards, it’s pretty much done.

The other type of extractors are good too and can be used more than once. I think they’re easier to use with an impact wrench than with a breaker bar or ratchet, and hammering the extractor on works way better than trying to hammer a 12pt socket on like other people try to recommend. Also if you go this route, don’t buy the cheapest possible Chinese ones off Amazon because they’re not going to bite well or last long. The Irwin ones are solid but they’re overpriced if you buy at the auto parts store. There’s a brand called Rocket Socket that you can find on Amazon and they’re supposed to be really good, not cheap but not overly expensive like some Snap On shit but they will be a livesaver for years to come.

posts.com:

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26299552
Could be a million things. Maybe it could be some intermittent electrical thing with some sensor if the car was still running ok. When it gets really cold, everything shrinks, so an older car with already worn wires, the metal and plastic could be shrinking a fraction of a millimeter and losing contact somewhere until stuff heats up. And for lots of those codes, you can trip it and then it takes a few miles of driving without seeing that lean condition again before it goes away on its own, so it obviously happens on those cold stretches.

That’s a generic code that’s going to be hard to diagnose until it pops up with another code or something more obvious happens. Those intermittent issues are a pain in the ass to track down unless you have the scanner with you right when it trips so you can see what the sensor is actually reading and try to troubleshoot it before it goes away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26300639
>saw multiple 15k(ish) examples sold, and I don't see anything particularly wrong with the cars.
Probably high mileage. The shitty part about those bmw v12's is that you can't rebuild a high mileage block, they have coated aluminum cylinders that can't be bored or honed so you're forced to find a lower mileage shortblock.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26301110
On the other hand the blocks are pretty stout and even at higher mileages they rarely wear out.
The 5 litre M70B50 can easily cover half a million kilometres without any issues, they're legit well made engines.
I had an M73B54 in an E38 that I pulled out and checked the cylinders, they were all still within factory specs, there was zero wear on the cylinders.
Even if there was some damage, M70 and M73 blocks are fairly common even today, mostly because they're not as popular as the M60 and M62 V8 engines due to being practically a dead end when it comes to aftermarket tuning.

You can bore out the M70 cylinders to oversize as the whole block is made from alusil, not just the cylinder liners like with older nikasil blocks.
Worst case scenario you can smack in an iron dryliner, albeit those are a bit iffy due to iron and aluminium not playing nice when heated up.

M60 used nikasil coatings on the cylinders, there's a company in Germany that does nikasil recoatings, M62 was alusil due to high sulphur fuels destroying nikasil coatings

I think it's a combination of two things;

One being the massive inflation we're experiencing. The cars aren't worth more, your money is worth less. Just like with all the other things you're buying, like groceries.

Two being the absurd delivery times for new cars. With the supply chain crisis that covid left us with, a lot of things became more scarce and hard to come by. People that would buy/lease a new car now have to wait like two years for it to arrive, so they start buying used cars instead as they are readily available. More demand for used cars, price goes up.

The beetle. When I was in high school in the early 80s like half the class drove one of these to school. They were fun, easy to maintain, durable, and really cheap. Engine blew up? The junkyard had a stack of used 1600cc engines for $80 each and it literally took an hour and some jack stands to do an engine swap in your back yard.

You could cut off the muffler and bolt on a stinger, run it rich and throw on a switch operated spark plug in the exhaust to shoot flames out the back. Or you could adjust the torsion tubes to lift it and make it an offroader. There hasn't been a better teenager car since.

>>26296143
I know that GRID 1 had licenced 2006 Le Mans, FIA GT and IMSA drivers, teams and liveries in it.
The main reason I know that, is because I still have some very worn out Spyder Squadron vests and merchandise from back then, and given how often I played GRID 1 then, I definitely recognize many of the cars and liveries of that season. It's pretty fun how the drivers from licenced teams swapped each other out every championship while being on the same team.
Looking at the screenshots showing those liveries, even most sponsors on the cars are about 90% accurate on the licenced cars.
I have a model car of the PSI Experience Chevrolet Corvette C6-R #34 that Jos Menten drove in the 2006 FIA GT series, and the livery that's in GRID is mostly accurate to that, although the car number might differ during the races. It certainly was the time licencing was a lot easier, seeing how many small sponsors were on those licenced team cars.
I think the Japanese GT2 events used mostly fictional teams and liveries though due to the Porsche 911 GT3-RSR and the Ferrari 430 GT2 not being available to the player during career mode, thus you suddenly got a grid filled only with Panoz Esperante GT2 and Spyker C8 Spyder GT2 cars from fictional teams, which in real life were only ran by Multimatic Autosports / Team LNT and Spyker Squadron respectively in that season.
It were really simpler times back then.

Yeah, looking back at screenshots of liveries of licenced cars in Grid 1 made me actually a bit sad looking at how detailed they are, and how many small sponsors are on it that aren't involved in autosports anymore, or are even in business anymore. I think the last time Codies remotely gave a fuck about livery design, was Dirt Rally 1, given how they got some obscure BRC liveries in from 2015-2016 and the other liveries still resembled some IRL liveries from other racing series. (Example, the standard Evo X livery in Dirt Rally 1 resembled the Ohlins Racing livery from Grid 1's DLC Evo X). After Dirt Rally 1, they just tossed any sort of livery in a quick livery editor, and called it a day there.
That said, Spyker Squadron was pure SOVL, and it is sad that they went under in a desperate attempt to save Saab in 2011. Truly too soulful for their own good.
>>26296237
No, it was due to some crazy licencing shenanigans in the month before GRID 1 was supposed to be released. If you remember, Porsche had an exclusive licence with Electronic Arts for the Need For Speed games at the time, which meant that while the AI could drive Porsche 911 GT3 RSR cars in GRID 1, the player couldn't buy or drive them for his own team, only for the licenced teams for a series hire or for the licenced teams in a non-career event. The three teams running the Porsches in the game are all driven by licenced drivers, there is not a single fictional team allowed to drive them. Ferrari also was considering an exclusivity deal around that time, and decided to jank their licence for GRID 1 at the last minute, leading to the Ferrari 430 GT2 and Ferrari 550 Maranello GT1 cars to be cut just for release, which meant traces of those cars were still in the game files at launch, despite being unusable for anyone in the game!

A GT-like game that takes time and place into consideration. You can choose the exact year your career starts from the 80s to the present day. Whatever specific year and series you're competing in has the same competitors from that season. Where you start out also influences how your career progresses just as much. If you begin in the US, you could work your way up through short track oval racing instead of road circuits. The used cars available to you will also change depending on location.

Mobile version dumbs things down considerably and is functionally an arcade mode. Loot boxes are exclusively for player cosmetics and customizing your garage.

>>26299438
>no real life series
They didn’t have the license, but GT4 had the then-current LMP and Super GT cars and most of the tracks they would’ve raced on. They also had a fantasy F1 car based on a 2003-era car and several F1 tracks from that era. Nearly all of the IB, IA, and S license races were replicas of realworld championships. The actual license tests were hard progression locks to make it feel like you were following the path of a real racing driver. No license and all you could do is bottom barrel club events. B and A gave you access to national-level professional stuff, IB and IA gave high class professional, and S gave you access to top level stuff. No other racing sim has had the level of career progression that GT has.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26298351
>EV also use roads. Therefore EV need to be taxed.
EVs are taxed. They pay higher registration fees which translates into more per mile than gas cars pay. EV fast charging is also taxed, with fees substantially more than the gas tax per gallon equivalent.

>That is not consumer petrol
It is. You may not like the facts but that's the reality.

The only reason that electric cars have caught on is they don't need subsidies for their operating costs. Meanwhile biodiesel, ethanol, synthetic fuels, or hydrogen haven't caught on because all of those alternatives for running internal combustion engines can't compete against heavily subsidized fossil fuels without major subsidies of their own, and none of them have the kind of nation wide lobbying power that fossil fuels have to make that happen.
Nobody is going to pay $.21 a mile to drive on hydrogen when gasoline is $.10 a mile. But if electric cars are still $.04 a mile even with all the extra fees they pay then its no question why people are switching.
Simple economics. The invisible hand of the market favors electric cars because they're cheaper to run.

1) Hit local hardware store
2) Acquire round hickory tool handle about 20 inches long and 1.5 inches in diameter
3) Use a thin, round wood rasp for the four grooves around the handle
4) Use a flat wood rasp to round rown the edges at both ends
5) Drill a hole for the lanyard
6) Sand down the entire thing with #100 or so grid paper
7) Cover it in boiled linseed oil and let dry for about a week
Ta-daa, hickory bonker for no more than 10 bucks if you got the basic tools at home.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a while, I've had a book that lists every single Italian auto manufacturer. There's a brief section on OPES (Officine di Precisione E Stampaggio), the first new manufacturer in post-war Italy. Their only car, the Ninfea, was a FWD sedan that came with a 702cc or 784cc 3 cylinder engine. After a prototype was made in Turin in 1946, it was showcased at an auto show there in 1948. They obtained 100 orders, but financial issues caused the company to fold before they could fulfill any of them.

The only images online of it seem to come from a single brochure. Of the handful of examples made, I don't think any are extant.

>>26275735
No. It wasn't even a real serial production - it was an initiative research project by some engineers and designers of Central Scientific Research Automobile and Automotive Engines Institute (NAMI for short). Six cars that they made remained in their personal posession. All of them had air cooled V4 at the rear from different ZAZ models.
There was a noticeable movement of self-made automobiles in USSR, with conventions and articles in tech journals like "Technics for the youth". One of the most prominent of the constructors and his son are hosting YT channels "Combat Crew" and "Combat Crew Live" which has detailed videos about their projects (most famous one, Laura, is on the pic), maybe you will be able to understand something with YT subtitles. Also, one of the most popular youtubers found one of the soviet self-made cars on sale, fixed it and made an interview with the old man who made it:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLiCpP_44QZBz9D1Cp8f2Qp1auev7EKqpi

posts.com:
I'm trying to chase lean and fuel trim codes on my 2005 sportage, 2.7 v6.
Bank 1 long term sits around 14.8% and bank 2 sits around 14.1, dousing the running engine in brake cleaner doesn't really provoke a change in either short term bank trim. Downstream o2 sensors occasionally spike above 1v.
Should the next step be new downstream sensors or getting a gauge for fuel pressure?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26289879
Put it in park, set the parking brake, then release the foot brake. The car shouldn't move at all. You could also set the parking brake, put it into park, and then release the foot brake. The order doesn't matter as long as you don't release the foot brake before you set the parking brake.
If you put it in park and release the foot brake and then set the parking brake the car will roll a little bit when you release the foot brake as the parking pawl settles in to a slot which can really wedge it in there if you're on a hill and make it tough to shift back into gear when you want to leave.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26292184
it's doubtful both o2 sensors are going bad at the same time. i would carefully check for vacuum leaks (buy or borrow a smoke machine if you can), clean your maf sensor, and run some strong fuel injector cleaner. possibly take your fuel injectors out and clean/test their spray pattern. since both banks are bad, that would make me lean toward the maf or a vacuum leak. i wouldn't just start replacing parts until you narrow down the actual problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296249
Generally an alternator should survive being blasted with a water hose. If you live in an area with a lot of salt then chances are parts of it can corrode internally. Is the alternator not charging at all? You should try to stick a multimeter to the battery poles with the car running and check the voltage. If it's less than 14V you probably have a bad alternator. As long as the power and ground are connected to it it should produce power. I don't know about the electrical system design on your 09 Jetta but on my 94 Audi the power regulator is also a known failure point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296378
the battery recharges while running, but it drains while the car is off. I have the new (used) alternator in hand ready to install

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296468
Doesn't sound like an alternator problem to me then - if that was the case the battery would also die on you while the car is running.

Generally if you have battery drain then I recommend you start checking what might be drawing battery. Sometimes you'll find there are certain modules locking themselves in ON position and powering things while the car is off. Try pulling fuses and stick a multimeter into the ports - stick the pins into the fuse holes and make sure you get good contact. Any reading which is near 0 or 0 is good. If your battery dies once a week or so, assuming it holds 60Ah you could have a fairly high draw. If you see values above 0.2A you might have your answer there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296511
Actually - I've done some reading on alternator diodes now and it seems like in some cases a faulty diode can discharge your battery and lead to a parasitic draw. I guess the best way of checking that is by disconnecting the main power line to the alternator and checking to see if there is amperage when the car is off to the alternator between the line and the alternator itself. If not then go back to previous plan of pulling and checking fuses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26298558
First jump the computer to blink out the codes, that might be an important clue. If that doesn't yield anything, put on a fuel pressure gauge and see if your pressure is ok. Also check your spark plugs, plug wires, cap and rotor for obvious problems (cracks, tracks, carbon buildup etc). Make sure your air filter isn't clogged/replace if due. Check for excessive carbon buildup in the throttle body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26298558
you say its a fuel related issue so i'll assume that it is.

generally speed isnt as interesting, but look at rpm. if it struggles with supplying fuel at higher rpm, and this applies to every cylinder (ruling out individual injectors) id instantly suspect fuel pump. youd want to check fuel pressure.

i dont think your car has O2 sensors, but they fuck up fuel trim sometimes if theyre broken. these also tend to trip trouble codes if theyre broken.

the last thing i can imagine then would be the ECM itself, but then youd probably have trouble code, also ECM failure is uncommon unless its been shorted or soaked.

If the radio head works and the display is just burned out, you can still use a regular $20 transmitter. Union work is insane.

On a Saturday.
On a holiday.

Because it was a holiday and a Saturday, that's 2.5x pay.
Crane operator base pay is $75 an hour.
So $187.50 an hour to sit at a little table inside the elevator and watch movies and push buttons on occasion when someone needs to get to a different floor.

Technically, it's the differential of forces across your body that kills you. Uniform application of gravity = fine. Non-uniform application of the dashboard to your face = not fine. You're going to have problems if your brain is moving and your skull isn't.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26274024
I'll reiterate a couple of points and add on a few things from the last time I talked about it, a large reason we didn't want to work on it is because of the aforementioned but there's a large list of things that piled on top of one another and we just don't feel like doing it anymore.

- We're spending money on production that could be used for that sticker on other products instead. Pre-orders are gone, and we don't want to create a 6 week lead time (pre-order + production).

- I worked briefly with desuprint who informed me of issues with production, a large one being that Taiyo works in Inkscape primarily and the design would have to be completely rebuilt in Illustrator along with the white ink layer. desuprint also had the foil we wanted to do it on, however he has told me a while ago he is unable to reproduce it. The cost in paying him to print the stickers would be exploiting and underpaying him, or it would end up charging the customer out the ass. Paying over $10 for a sticker is stupid, and that's ironic because my store will only offer tracked shipping in the future and I apologize for any international orders because shipping is literally going to eat people's asses.

- Many things have been on my backlog for a while. In the past 6 months, nearly every original Taiyo design has been under renovation along with new(er) projects. I reflected over my FOTM drop and figured it wasn't something I wanted to force myself to do like I did before after Grandmasterslices gave me input that made me realize I was pushing myself way too hard and getting frustrated over nothing.

tl;dr no thanks, see you when the store is open someday.

posts.name: b/o/t
posts.com:
>The GR Corolla is not as well balanced or as rally capable as the GR Yaris.

The GR Corolla and GR Yaris have some distinctions, however, they share many similar components, making them largely comparable in terms of technicality.

>Can you buy a regular Yaris in America and make it into a GR Yaris with aftermarket parts?

The Toyota GR Yaris is not available in the American market. Importing the vehicle from another country may seem like an option, but it is important to note that US import laws only allow vehicles that are 25 years or older to be brought in. Attempting to import a GR Yaris would not be compliant with these regulations and would not be viable.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26283070
Is the audi 4.2 reliable compared with most german powerplants?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281331
Why tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26284175
A lot of those older VAG engines are pretty solid, the main things to look out for on the 4.2 in particular are the intake manifold flaps (actuators tend to fail over time, making for less low-end torque) and the coil packs (which can be retrofitted for more modern ones with a simple adapter kit).
Chain-driven 4.2 40Vs are a different story (they're a nightmare), 4.2 FSIs still need the occasional major expensive service but they're less likely to slap you with it out of the blue like the chain-driven 40Vs do.

Reminder thats how the clio v6 was born.

An initial idea to drop in the turbocharged three-cylinder 12-valve engine from the Daihatsu Charade GTTi was scorched by problems mating up the electronics, but rather than scaling back his ambitions, Bruen went even wider, He began looking for a car with a wheelbase that would match the 92.3-inch (2345 mm) Twingo’s, and found one in the Ferrari 308 (92.1 inches, 2340 mm), which had a separate chassis, so theoretically could be fairly easily fused with the little Renault.


“The good thing was that the Ferrari came from a different [older] period, so the track was not that wide, whereas the Twingo, for its category was a very wide car,” remembers Breun.

But although he persuaded Renault to donate an unused Twingo shell and came close on more than one occasion to buying an accident-damaged 308 to get the project really rolling, Breun couldn’t quite pull the funds together to make it happen.

Good deal, no. No good deals have existed for two years. Hold out for the recession if you want a good deal. It's coming, don't know when. (Two more weeks meme goes here.)
If you're willing to spend it, it's a great truck. They really don't make them like they used to -- they legally can't. Modern diesels get ducked with all kinds of dpf and related fuckery.
My 7.3l (f350) has 342k miles. recently threw a cel which I believe to be a IPR issue, but it has some fluid leaks and I'm itching for more power so I took that as my excuse to give her some love. Planning a turbo swap, injectors and supporting mods, will be about $5k but get me ~500 hp and still be reliable to tow a 10k trailer. Could go buy a newer truck, but don't want to because the 7.3 is a 5 speed and because I like it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26300478
Honestly, the 7.3l sold literally over 2 million units over more than 10 years, and that's not counting the idi was based on. It was in Ford pickup trucks, school buses, commercial box trucks, boats (under a merceuiser badge), all kinds of shit. It only went out of production because of emissions bs (and a splash of Ford getting cheap); had Congress and the EPA not meddled they'd probably be running a tuned up version of it today.
And yeah, it isn't powerful by today's standards but the idi naturally aspirated diesel it replaced was a whopping 165 HP so 225 felt great at the time. If you want to put a little money into it, the older forged rod motors can take like 700 hp reliably, just gotta play with tune, turbo (plus piping including intercooler,) and fuel (pump to injector, plus HPOP.) If you don't want to put that much money a $180 chip tune gets you around 15 extra horse with nothing else done.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26292407
How little do you know about 4 cylinder high revving motorcycles?

A 4 cylinder 400cc bike is going to have tiny overbore cylinders, which means it's going to rev high and make good power up top, yes, but will be like a fucking moped at low revvs. This is going to drastically shorten the life if you just scream it around town, and it's going to suck to constantly row the gear box to avoid screaming around town everywhere. The 400 p-twin, on the other hand, will make less peak power, but it has two big meaty 200cc cylinders that product ample bottom end power to get you down the road. A 600cc 4 cylinder makes enough at the bottom end to still do what it needs but then goes full rocket ship when revv'd out. This is just basic physics and core engine knowledge, try reading a book sometime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281079
The more difficult part when i did the change on mine was getting the end links in. Getting the old bar out and new one in was fairly simple.
Si springs can be swapped over as well. 10mm drop, front spring rate is 7% higher (144.2lbs/in vs 126.8lbs/in) while the rears are 32% stiffer (208.8lbs/in vs 158.5lbs/in). Should help with reducing body roll/improving weight transfer, noticed with mine that it feels a bit wallowy when being pushed hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281787
Yeah that was my problem lol. Ended up unbolting the endlinks from the sway bar and bolting them to the control arm first, then the sway bar. I also thought of installing Si springs to keep her OEM+ but I want a modest drop, so I'm installing Eibach Pros next week. So far I've installed a Type R shift assembly, subframe brace, DC strut bar, this sway bar, and soon the springs. I'm out of ideas for what next. Maybe brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281892
Brakes are a decent choice. DC5R calipers bolt straight on to the knuckle and go well with S2000 rotors, another option would be the Genesis Coupe Brembos paired with Rogue disks. DC5 Creations has a remachined TL Type S caliper that also directly bolts on (OEM ones use an M14 bolt rather than M12), need to use the TL-S rotors for that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281900
nice i'll look into those

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281900
>>26281950
btw are those plug and play or would I need to mod anything else? I've heard changing front calipers could throw off brake bias and/or mess with ABS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281957
They should all be plug-n-play for the most part, bias will be more towards the front but the ABS should be able to figure it out. Just a warning though, the DC5R calipers will be the most expensive out of everything, over $1000 for a pair. Genesis coupe calipers are $700 from SlickFab, and the remachined TL-S ones are $515 at minimum if you're getting new calipers (will be less if you send in ones to be remachined)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296107
l6s have perfect primary and secondary balance.
im still unable to fully wrap my head around it, but the primary balance is due to how each piston has an equivalent one going up with it, cancelling out forces that would otherwise result in excessive vibrations. v6s typically need counterweights or countershafts because they are basically two l3 engines side by side.
the secondary balance is perfect because the crank throws (distance from center of crank, to center of the crankpin (where the piston conrod connects to the crank)) are evenly spaced at 120 degree intervals, if you were to look at such a crank head on, the pins would be evenly spaced, kinda like a 3 blade fan.
all this makes for a very smooth running engine with very smooth power delivery.
the problems with an l6 is that it makes for a pretty long engine, so the engine bay has to either be large, or like some euro cars (i think bmw does this with some of theirs), they tuck the rear of the engine under the windscreen wiper cowl so if you need to do any work around there, you need to take off the wipers. this also creates a challenge for today's cars that need to meet safety regs that get tighter and tighter every year; it's quite difficult to make sure that in a head-on crash, the engine block does not go into the passenger cabin.
another is crankshaft torsional vibrations, every time a piston fires the force generated exerts a twisting motion upon the crank. longer cranks will flex, and the straight 6 crank is quite long. This is typically countered with a nice fat harmonic balancer on the end of the crank that isn't connected to the gearbox.
the video below has a great explanation about engine balance
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTS48jX68YU

Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

>>26288085
I fucking hate fat modern trucks as much as anyone, but as a '77 F150 owner I need to point out a couple errors in those pictures. First, the old truck in the first pic is 2wd vs a 4wd new truck. If you got a 4wd truck back in the old days it came with a factory lift. As an aside, compared to today's "it snows where I live so I need 4wd" in the old days 4wd trucks weren't even in the same catalog as the main product line. It was assumed normal people bought 2wd trucks, even if they had to sometimes go a little offroad. Then you had the special catalog for loggers and hunters with the 4wd trucks.

Second, in the second pic they're comparing a long bed old truck vs short bed newer trucks. Beds didn't magically get shorter in 1980. You always could choose an 8' or 6.5' bed. You can still get a single cab, 8' bed truck even if they're not big sellers. And the newer trucks in that pic are crew cab models which by default. People buy more crewcab trucks with tiny beds because it's just a way to have an SUV without driving the same car as your wife. I think the only truck combo you can't get any more is crew cab/long bed. They look retarded but they were a thing in the '70s.

>I typically I fall for all the bullshit I see on here about how half tons can tow so little
I don't know who's saying that. A modern half ton can tow more than a 3/4 ton of the past (on paper) though that doesn't mean you should ever be towing at your max tow. A 3/4 ton can tow more because it has beefier brakes, axles, driveline, transmission and engine cooling. You also have a stronger frame with a bigger wheelbase so you get more stability. The engine doesn't matter that much. Memestreams might be aerodynamic but they're definitely not light and most of the double axles models should be towed behind a 3/4 ton, same with livestock and heavy equipment trailers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26299300
>what am I in for
Oil leaks. Pic related is a good one. It's not the oil pan but rather the case-half seal. The case-half is basically the bottom of the block cut off through the middle of all the main bearings and so it has all the main bearing caps in one large plate. This means you have to pull all the main bearing bolts out which in turn guarantees at least one thread repair since it will pull the threads out of at least one hole.

to be continued

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26299300
rear main leak

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26300110
Do you have to drop the cradle to replace the rear main?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26300197
Another favorite is the head gaskets leaking oil into the center valley. The heads receive pressurized oil from a galley that's on the inboard side of the cylinders between the right two cylinders on the pictured rear head and between the two left front cylinders you can't see here.This means that when the head gaskets do leak oil it goes into the center valley first, as seen starting here at the lower left, and will fill the valley until the starter is half submerged in oil where the oil will leak out behind the flywheel and mimic a rear main seal leak.

And again this will result in at least one thread repair because GM still cannot into aluminum.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26300221
Coolant leaks.

A common spot for these to leak is from the coolant manifold to engine seals which are silicone and were no more durable here than they were on the 60 degree V6's because GM also cannot into silicone either. Well that's not quite true, the silicone is fine but the plastic form that holds it deteriorates and allows it to be pushed out under pressure. As seen in the picture there are four points of failure, one on each head, and one on each bank of cylinders. This manifold runs across the back of the engine above the trans bellhousing and is a complete pita to inspect. Luckily these don't usually pull any threads. Usually.

Oh and an odd-man-out failure that's common it the boot between the throttle body and the intake manifold splits in one of the folds and makes the thing run like shit and since a boot in that location is about as expected as the Spanish Inquisition many techs will miss it and claim the problem is something far more serious

Yeah, pulling the engine out the top sounds like a huge pain in the dick if it even fits. Dropping the cradle was far easier, basically just the wiring harness, fuel lines, abs module inlet lines, the two rear brake lines that conveniently have two fittings aft of the front subframe so you can drop the lines with the subframe, steering shaft, unbolt and hang the calipers, remove the strut to knuckle bolts, and 8 bolts/nuts for the subframe and it's down. The whole job paid about 24 hours.

>>26300026
Covid prices have fucked up the market, but a few years ago you couldn't give away a Northstar Cadillac. Even the later ones aren't known to be completely reliable, and luxury cars in general will have expensive upkeep as small gadgets break. Most of the people buying these things fall into two categories: 1. Rich old people who bought them new and keep so clean you could eat off them. 2. Poor niggers who found one for $1500 and thought "damn imma baller now" and they scrap it after driving it for a year with no maintenance. Used luxury cars are cheap precisely because it doesn't make economic sense for most people to keep them running. Like in the 2010s you could get V12 BMWs for a grand in decent shape because repairs are soul-sucking.

Realtalk: You sound like you have limited funds. Buying the first car you find out of desperation isn't a good idea, and buying an old American luxury car when you don't have much money is a terrible idea. Something like a 2000s Camry or Corolla or whatever would be much, much easier for you to keep going in the long run.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26286545
Bull bars typically mount to/under the bumper and then wrap upwards without any additional support which causes any force applied to the top where you expect it to provide protection (like hitting a deer) to multiply the energy on the mounts (like using a breaker bar on stubborn bolts) and the entire bull bar folds in.
That's why we talk shit about them being a force multiplier- they wind up causing more damage then they prevent.

A bull bar can be modified to provide legitimate protection but that is much more of an involved installation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The last of the trve sovl BMWs before they got fat, ugly, and boring to drive in the F-Series Cars alongside the E92 M3 (another classic).

>Reliable, the same N52/6spd drivetrain from a base model 3-Series, no real problems other than coilpacks and oil leaks (valve cover gasket, oil filter houising) at higher miles
>Tons of documentation + aftermarket like every BMW product
>IMPORTANT: Same dimensions as the classic 1990s BMWs. Literally the same length, weight as a E36 M3. Same horsepower too, at 230hp (2012) vs 240hp (1995) just with a open diff. Slightly wider and with a longer wheelbase. Hydraulic Steering so tons of feel vs the older cars.
>IMPORTANT: Overshadowed by the 135i drag/highway pull niggers so they're $4000-10,000 all day long, was BMWs cheapest car in the early 2010s

Give it a rear end upgrade (Decent LSD like a Quaife or OSGiken + higher gears), a good exhaust, and you'll have a ton of fun. And you'll avoid all the bullshit problems the older cars get like the floors trying to tear out or VANOS. Its 230hp/3200lbs in a FR with good steering and suspension, you cannot possibly lose. You can get a extra 20-30hp switching to a 330i/X3 3.0 Intake Manifold and tune

Honestly I'd be pressed between buying one or a 100k mile '13-'15 BRZ/FRS for the same money. The latter is more common, but the BMWs are cheaper and more fun. If you spend more money get a E92 M3 as a project and enjoy the best sports car you can buy (8400rpm ITB'd V8 with 414hp in a 3600lb FR with the best chassis/steering of sports cars from that time period). If you're a Euro all applies to the 130i.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26294891
The ninth gen Pontiac Bonneville.
I was looking for a new car after my '05 Ford Five Hundred got wrecked and I snagged what's probably the cleanest 1994 SE that exists for exactly $2,800. Even had the original order form, window sticker, and other documentation from the dealership/first owner in the manual. Pretty neat.
It's a fun car to drive and has one of the best/most reliable engines ever built (Buick 3800 V6). Motorweek has a really good review on the '93 model year and it's a great car. I've seen a good number of 2000 - 2005 Bonnevilles on the road throughout the years (not even seeing many of those as I used to these days though), but I have only seen another 90s Bonneville once in my entire life (I first started driving in 2004).
And I only saw that one about two weeks ago. Never once before that. I'm not sure how rare of a car it is (probably rare in the sense that it suffered the same fate as 95% of contemporary domestics and that was they were driven, abused beyond all repair, and then scrapped; engines were probably harvested too), but I do believe it's very underappreciated vehicle.
It's just very nice.

>>26276707
ID a local mechanic who has experience in the car. Go to the seller, tell him you want a "third party inspection", there's a mechanic shop down the way, yadda yadda, and have him drive it down there with you. Go on a ride along with the mechanic. The mechanic will drive the car, check the radio, look at the engine, whatever, tell you if it's a good buy or if there are any problems. If there are, then that gives you a talking point for price deductions. Pay the mechanic a couple hundred for the inspection, it's worth it.
t. just bought a 2012 bmw z4, had a third party inspection, the seller had to fix a leak the mechanic identified, saved me $1k, everyone was happy and it was all professional.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26285323
oh it's an e60, those tend to get real transmission problems. I would have the codes read by a competent bmw shop first. Most of the time with e60's they need valve body seals replaced and a fluid/filter change and possibly solenoids depending on the mileage. Sometimes you do need to have the valve body rebuilt. But you won't know what's wrong with it until you pull up which code the transmission threw. But if it's shifting perfectly fine, no harsh downshifts/upshifts, not clunking when coming to a dead stop, has no delay when going into reverse and no harsh park engagement it most likely needs valve body seals and a fluid and filter change.

>>26298463
From an engineering standpoint it's good. It's more efficient and quieter than a chain and lasts twice as long as a belt. But it doesn't take in to account that people including mechanics don't either know of manufacturer oil specifications or don't believe they affect anything. Wrong additives will bloat and degrade the belt really fast. Combine that with the suggested change interval of 150k miles and it's no wonder that ecoboosts blew up left, right and center. Wet belt horror stories are user error induced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26298647
>efficient and quieter than a chain
Chains are at or near 99% efficiency, and properly lubricated, are near silent. Trading a tried, true, and absurdly reliable system that can handle all sorts of sub-par conditions and lack of decent oiling without failing for a retarded belt drive system that is finicky and picky about running conditions, and objectively isn't as efficient is clearly a stupid bean-counter solution and not a smart engineering choice.

>>26295104
For other anons: This is an "H-Plate" or "H-Kennzeichen".
H stands for historic.
If your car is at least 30 years old you can have it examinated by an appraiser. If it aint fucked up or modified beyond recognition you can have it registred as a vehicle of historical value - this sounds much harder than it is in practice.
That means the entire taxation changes. Instead of being taxed based on engine displacement, fuel and emission class you pay a fixed tax which has been 192 Euros annualy for a coumple of years now.
Maths-wise this pays off starting at around 0.7 liters if your car has the lowest emission class. Means if you got a higher displacement you pay more if you got a regular registration.

But wait, there's more: No matter how bad your old dirty diesel or whatever smokes, no matter how bad the emission values are, you are free to drive into every emission controlled zone all over germany.

>>26300090
>Made for some sort of gas mileage regulatory compliance.
In the US it was introduced as a way to buff corporate fuel economy fleet averages. It did not meet the lofty 50-60mpg target goal, as the short body did very poorly in highway speeds, and the baseline steel wheels offered was roughly double the unsprung rotational mass of the optional alloy rims. It sold poorly, being panned for being too small and too slow for Americans, and not competitively fuel efficient or cheap compared to subcompact competition. It should also be mentioned that US auto journos routinely shit on subcompacts and economy cars anyways, being used to high output cars, trucks, and SUVs to promote.

In Europe the Cygnet was introduced to meet emissions fleet averages for Aston Martin as it was struggling at the time and was definitely not going to meet emissions averages for their V12 and V8 engines. Aston used the iQ as a platform and ended up coachbuilding a new interior for it, even producing a one-off V8 variant for a customer. The iQ was seen as a smarter Smart car with more maneuverability, but ultimately did not succeed since even Europeans don't really need a city car this small unless they're a city slicker. The upsized Aygo is better sized for the vast majority of Europeans.

In its home country of Japan, it got awards for its engineering, but ultimately it was a compact version of the Yaris. Despite its size, it did not qualify for kei car status due to its dimensions (too wide) so it fell into obscurity, being more inconvenient to own than a kei car.

>>26293295
It makes me feel old to remember all of this. My dad surprised my mother with one in 2000. Neighbors would be in the driveway pressed up against the glass. I was 12 and also thought it was rhe coolest thing. Acquired my license in it. It worked for over 14 years as far as the powertrain. The back adjustment lever on the seat snapped and broke off right at the base, maybe 8-9 years in. Dad never got it fixed. The seat is still locked in that very same position to this day, across 3 semi-permanent drivers since. Including the time my younger brother cosplayed as a part-time drug lord and semi-crashed it in the parking lot of a Piggly Wiggly grocery store two states away and got it impounded two states away. Dad had to tow it 400mi back home but I refused to go with him to help. He died shortly after and I wish I had gone with him to have that one last chance to bond with dad, over this absolute piece of shit Fischer Price Tupperware Amerishit car. It's just rotting away behind mom's garage now, like a redneck memorial to him and our family. If I ever become solely responsible for it I will let any mofo that wants it come and haul it away no questions asked. Fuck the PT Cruiser. Car of the Year? Car of my life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26290814
>Lasted maybe a month before they warped
Rotors don't warp.

Either you have uneven pad deposits on the rotor from not properly bedding in brakes.
Or there is a hardspot on the rotor which cannot be machined out.

More likely the former.
Put some semi-metallic pads on the car.
Bed them in by doing ~10 slow downs from 60-10MPH, don't stop. Best to do this on a highway. Like slowing down at a short offramp, nothing dramatic, no ABS or traction control activation.
By the 6th timethe shaking will get worse, but the 8th time the shaking will subside, by the 10 slow down there should be no more shaking.
After this 10th slow down take the car for 20min drive without stopping to cool down the rotors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26299683
It wouldn't be cheaper.

Firstly any R32 you see for cheap in japan is most certainly not in desirable condition. People in japan who are into that market know how much they're worth in export and god only knows whats wrong with it. Its not uncommon for parts to be stolen, non-matching engines, or stolen VIN numbers all together.
Secondly, you can't just "import it yourself" There are a ton of hoops you have to go through. You'll need an exporter to get it out of japan, you'll need an importer to get it into japan overall you'll need a broker to manage this exchange.
TLDR any cheap JDM car you see there is largely bullshit if its not coming from a reputable dealer in export cars and you need a lot more involvement to actually get it to the states.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26288225
Distribution doesn't tell the whole story, another big factor is how far the mass sits away from the center of rotation (polar moment of inertia).
In a mid-engined car like an MR2, the mass sits very close to the center, which makes it very nimble and responsive, but prone to sudden snaps. The transaxle Porsches (924/944/968) have a heavy engine in the front and a heavy transmission in the back, which gives them a very nice 50/50 balance but also makes them very easy to keep under control. A 911 has a lot of weight way out at the back, which gives it a lot of traction but makes it pretty scary to drive at the limit with that pendulum-like rear end that just wants to keep swinging round every corner.
Subarus and longitudinal Audis have a lot of weight way out in front, which makes them resist turn-in more than other drivetrain layouts. That big engine lump wants to keep going straight most of all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Having owned a C4 S6 and B5 S4, you can absolutely race Audis, but just know that they aren't the best chassis for it and make far better autobahn/comfy canyon road cars. Post B4/C4/D1 the cars got the famous Audi 4 link front suspension which has an immense benefit towards reducing understeer vs the MacPherson front of early cars, along with the adoption of shorter V6/V8 engines (often aluminum) vs inline 5s. Also post B7/C6 got the newer style transmissions which move the engine back about 4 inches, putting the bellhousing flange directly centered with the front axle.

Rear swaybars help a lot but in poor conditions like rain you can't increase front grip with a swaybar, only better tire selection.

tl;dr they make great fast daily drivers but there are better handling chassis out there, mostly on the basis of being lighter weight more so than being front heavy.
>>26288225
You can't compare weight distribution just as a %/%, because light weight cars always get fucked. If a B5 RS4 is ~3500 lbs, then the 500 lb engine + 200 lb transmission is a big part of that, compared to an RS6 which is ~5000 lbs with around the same engine+trans weight.

Obviously a car with more front weight is going to have a tendency towards understeer IN A RELATIVE SENSE, as in, likely the front wheels will lose grip before the rears ON THAT CAR. You can't compare %/% between cars that weigh differently.

posts.com:
Audis do not feel like shit on the track. I track my S6 routinely.

The weight over the front axle is real, but is less real every generation. It’s not 1985. Even the V8 in the S4 is as small as the old inline 5.

You have to understand the new corvette and the 911 C2S come with understeer dialed in from the factory because it’s safer.

Audi has poor weight distribution (so does a 911 really). But it also has maximum traction in any given scenario. The S and RS cars also have a torque splitting differential. You turn right and the outside rear wheel will overdrive and you’ll find the car oversteers when driven properly. The understeer meme is either out of date, Related to the old S3 and under or a misunderstanding of what understeer is.

You can feel the weight of the engine when you turn an Audi. Normal fags such as Doug demuro mistake this for ‘understeer’ and indeed it can contribute to understeer. But understeer does not occur unless the front tires have reach maximum traction and can no longer turn anymore and they are not turning enough. This does not occur on the street. It does not occur even in a golf R until the tires get too hot after a few laps.

The Audi S cars come with a rather aggressive -2.5 camber stock. I adjust mine to -3.0. I added a rear sway bar that’s slightly stiffer than an RS. I find the car understeers in a manageable way with the torque splitting rear diff on tap to turn in the nose of the car.
It’s very good Imo, considering it’s a street car. Yes the new corvette does not have the sensation of weight in front of you but the reality is that it understeer roughly the same as my Audi due to the nature of the suspension geometry.

Consider now as well the 911. The engine is in the back. You get better traction on the rear wheels but when the gas is applied that extra traction is taken from the front wheels. The result is understeer.

And 911s and mid engines also have a higher risk of oversteer which can be very expensive if it goes wrong unlike understeer which is easy to manage. Go down the grid at an Indy or F1 race where the cars are ‘neutral’ by design and you’ll find drivers still prefer under or oversteer dialed in depending on their style.

The upside to Audi is power and traction. The downside is weight and where the weight is. Idk if Audi has ever made a light weight car. The real downside is the computer and traction management in an S car will constantly be fighting you on track in little ways. It’s too aggressive. It works very well but at the cost of your brake pads. Have to VAG com it down as much as possible.

As long as you drive an Audi like an AWD car and play to its strengths they’re excellent fun on track. But you can’t drive it like a Caymen and then complain it’s not ‘as good’. You just have to manage the weight and trail brake and hit the gas hard esrly to make the turn.

And 911s and all the rest are modded for the track anyway. Race cars have a set up for each track so driving a street car on the track and trying to compare them as if ones better is meaningless. And most guys like Doug demuro and onions pipes havnt got a basic understanding of race car or driving dynamics or suspension. So them saying Audis understeer is a bench racing stereotype from 1985

Look, I probably would keep watching the Grand Tour for the bants and the cinematography, like >>26269327 said, as this point I'm invested as a watcher. I really liked some of the episodes, like China and Cambodia/Vietnam. Even the RV episode was fun.

But in line with the majority of other comments, Grand Tour isn't really sure what it wants to be anymore. The studio "chat show" aspect is gone, and it's barely even a "car show" anymore. (Although part of that is due to larger cultural problems, since EU, USA, and other regions are in the process of legislatively killing real car culture. 2035 is fast approaching; what will you do?)

The more recent episodes are just heavily-scripted "adventure" in foreign countries with a few improvised bants that just happen to (sometimes) feature a few commercially-available cars. And I might even be fine with that... but it's annoying how the international aspect is so WASTED. They should have been leaning much more heavily into the local cultural aspect, taking cues from shows like Travel Man or even James May's own "Our Man in Japan/Italy" series. (What? You went to Sweden and Finland, and didn't even force the boys to eat surströmming and salmiakki for a gag?) They could have even returned somewhat to their car-show roots by delving into each country's transportation culture. (How to people get around? What vehicles do they use? Who makes them? What are future trends? Take some hints from May's old "Cars of the People.") But no, somehow it's more entertaining to use these lands as a backdrop for some obviously artificial real-life Wile E. Coyote hijinks. (My favorite part is when the trio talk about "modifying their cars" as if Clarkson is out in the garage operating a welder.)

posts.com: I have a 2004 Ford Escape and the oil light has been coming on intermittently for the last 6 months. It's only ever after the car is warmed up, and in the beginning the light would just lightly flicker when I came to a stop. That progressed to a steady light sometimes when I came to a stop, and currently the light will come on as I'm slowing down to stop. But it's so random - some days it won't come on at all, some days it comes on the first few times that I idle and then stops. It's practically impossible to reliably recreate it, and I've already had two shops tell me that it's either just a sensor going bad or there's something seriously wrong. Anyone have any hunches? I feel like if it's been happening for months and the car still seems to be running fine, it's probably more likely a bad sensor. The sensor has never been replaced as far as I know,

>>26296818
1. Oil level is low (or at threshold)
2. Oil pressure is low (or at threshold)
3. Oil temperature is high (or at threshold) Do the events occur with a corresponding High Temp (coolant)??
1.Check your Oil Quality and Level (better to just change Oil + Filter anyway, to start with KNOWN GOOD)
2.Replace the Oil Pressure Sensor (to ensure valid reading is being sent). If indicator still comes on, have Oil Pump replaced.
3.Is this model equipped with an Oil Cooler? It may be blocked or the Fins filled with bugs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had the exact same symptoms on my 3.5l Montero. Hot engine, hot day, idling and the low oil light would flicker or sometimes stay solid. As soon as I gave it gas it went away.

What I did was I removed the sensor and installed a T there. One side went to the sensor and the other side of the T went to a good quality aftermarket oil pressure gauge that I installed. My oil pressure never went below 12 psi so I knew it was the sensor acting up and not some other problem.
I'd recommend either changing your sensor or installing a good pressure gauge (if the car came with one you can't really trust it especially considering Ford).
You do need to determine whether it's a bad sensor or a real low oil pressure issue. If you can't do the above, I'd change the oil and filter and go with a heavier oil for now. Like if it's supposed to be 10w-30 try 10w-35 and that should help delay an engine failure if it is low pressure. You could have a blocked pickup tube or a bunch of sludge or some shit too though so that's why it's better to start with a pressure gauge or trying a new sensor rather than shooting in the dark..
